<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 904, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 360, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 699, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 892, 604]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 711, 904, 839]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 866, 725, 882]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 73, 737, 90]]<|/det|>
<pre>You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 96, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 103, 707, 122]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 135, 500, 153]]<|/det|>
• Connect the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 165, 834, 359]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.1</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 468, 427]]<|/det|>
• Ensure that the switch S is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 917, 475]]<|/det|>
• Slide the LDR leads into the tube until the front of the LDR is just level with the open end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 489, 918, 520]]<|/det|>
• With the LDR in this position, attach a piece of adhesive tape to the leads as a marker at the other end of the tube, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 881, 552]]<|/det|>
• Slide the tube until the LDR is approximately half-way along it, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 564, 720, 661]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.2</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Change \(x\) by moving the LDR to a new position inside the tube, with \(x\) in the range \(4 \text{cm}\) to \(18 \text{cm}\). Record \(x\) and \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 575, 136]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 147, 690, 167]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\sqrt{I}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 570, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 144, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 600, 180, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 652, 618]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\sqrt{I}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 631, 181, 649]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 631, 457, 648]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 631, 920, 649]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 661, 180, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 661, 606, 679]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 831, 915, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 861, 915, 878]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ....................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 879, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[57, 28, 412, 67]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 90]]<|/det|>
# You may not need to use all of the materials provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 94, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 732, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the elastic properties of rubber cord.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 134, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 180, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 134, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
You are provided with a wire with a clip and two slotted masses attached, as shown in Fig. 2.1.  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[257, 179, 737, 348]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 361, 532, 380]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.1 </center>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 393, 905, 411]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centres of the two slotted masses is \(B\) , as shown in Fig. 2.1.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 424, 386, 441]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(B\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 562, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<form>B = ................................................................................. [1] </text>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 594, 181, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 594, 814, 612]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(B\). Show your working.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[375, 796, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................................. % [1] </text>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 73, 833, 90]]<|/det|>
You are provided with two lengths of rubber cord. Select the longer cord.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 475, 121]]<|/det|>
The diameter of the cord is \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 135, 422, 152]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 180, 904, 197]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 211, 180, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 211, 917, 244]]<|/det|>
Suspend the clip, wire and masses using the longer cord secured in the two clips, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 253, 850, 647]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 660, 590, 677]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.2 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 691, 781, 708]]<|/det|>
• The length of cord between the two clips is \(L\) , as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 723, 422, 739]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 766, 904, 783]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 651, 90]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(T, B, L\) and \(d\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 101, 545, 130]]<|/det|>
\[T^{2} = \frac{B^{2}L}{kd^{4}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 139, 339, 155]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 170, 180, 187]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 170, 547, 187]]<|/det|>
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 370, 915, 387]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k =\) ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 402, 917, 419]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k =\) ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 418, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 448, 180, 466]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 448, 850, 465]]<|/det|>
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 570, 180, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 570, 749, 588]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(20\%\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 603, 827, 620]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in (d).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 744, 915, 761]]<|/det|>
......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 803, 915, 820]]<|/det|>
......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 833, 915, 850]]<|/det|>
......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 833, 920, 851]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
